;;小唐纳德·特朗普在媒体档案中心作为其父亲、美国前总统唐纳德·特朗普的代理人向媒体发表讲话， 2023 年 8 月 23 日，前总统缺席了在美国威斯康星州密尔沃基举行的 2024 年美国总统竞选首场共和党候选人辩论。 REUTERS/Jim Bourg/档案照片;
;

;唐纳德·特朗普的儿子唐纳德小特朗普将于周三下午在纽约民事欺诈审判中作证，指控这位美国前总统及其家族企业夸大资产价值，欺骗贷方和保险公司。

;

;执行副总裁小唐纳德 (Donald Jr.)特朗普集团总裁兼本案共同被告将是特朗普成年子女中第一个出庭作证的人，其次是埃里克·特朗普和伊万卡·特朗普。他们的父亲定于周一出庭作证。

;

;该审判是;遥遥领先;民意调查显示，共和党总统提名将在 2024 年 11 月的选举中面对民主党人乔·拜登。

;

;老特朗普还面临;四项单独的刑事起诉;，包括华盛顿和佐治亚州与他试图推翻 2020 年选举失败有关的案件。

;

;该诉讼由纽约州总检察长利蒂西亚·詹姆斯 (Letitia James) 指责特朗普、他的两个成年儿子以及他们的几家家族企业将资产夸大数十亿美元，以确保更好的贷款条件。

;

;特朗普否认有不当行为，并多次指控詹姆斯和法官审理政治偏见案件。

;

;他受到;有限禁言令;禁止他公开谈论法庭工作人员，但他两次违反该令，并因攻击阿瑟·恩戈伦法官的高级职员而被罚款 15,000 美元被指控存在偏见。

;

;华盛顿法官正在监督他的;联邦选举颠覆审判; 还施加了有限的禁言令。特朗普声称两者都侵犯了他的言论自由权。

;

;特朗普不需要出席审判，但偶尔会出庭，包括出席;与他的前律师兼调解人迈克尔·科恩戏剧性重聚;，后者上周出庭指控他的前任老板。;自五年前两人激烈决裂以来，科恩首次与特朗普面对面，他表示特朗普指示他夸大资产价值，以达到他想要的任意净资产。

;<目前尚不清楚特朗普是否会出席周三的审判。他定于周四在休斯敦举行竞选活动，届时埃里克·特朗普将出庭作证。

;

;小唐纳德与同案被告埃里克·特朗普在很大程度上从父亲手中接管了特朗普集团的管理权2017 年，他是此案的核心人物，掌管着特朗普房地产帝国皇冠上的明珠。

;

;他还曾成为他父亲的政治攻击狗，他的证词可能成为案件中的另一个导火索。庭审过程中，律师和证人之间的激烈交锋，以及关于证据可接受性的激烈争论。

;

;9月份，在庭审开始前，恩戈隆发现特朗普欺诈性地夸大了他的净资产，并下令解散控制公司的公司。他的房地产投资组合的支柱，包括曼哈顿的特朗普大厦。在特朗普上诉期间，该裁决被搁置。

;

;审判主要涉及损害赔偿。詹姆斯正在寻求至少 2.5 亿美元的罚款、永久禁止特朗普及其两个成年儿子在纽约经营企业，以及对特朗普和特朗普集团实施为期五年的商业房地产禁令。

; Wed, 01 Nov 2023 18:55:03 +0800 Fed poised to hold rates steady despite economy“s bullish tonehttps://reuters.com/article/usa-fed/fed-poised-to-hold-rates-steady-despite-economys-bullish-tone-idUSKBN31W2KY
;;2023-11-01T10:08:34Z;
;

;在与通货膨胀的两年斗争中，美联储试图通过提高利率来压榨消费者他们停止支出，使需求与供应保持一致，并使美国经济增长低于缓解价格压力的潜力。

;

;这还没有发生。

;

;金融市场预计美联储将在周三为期两天的政策会议结束时维持利率不变，政策制定者现在必须判断经济强于预期的表现是否是新冠疫情期间开始的消费者挥霍的最后一搏。 19 大流行，或者有证据表明货币政策仍然不够严格，不足以使通胀完全回到美联储 2% 的目标。

;

;自 9 月份上次政策会议以来，央行政策制定者也维持利率不变，即将公布的数据显示，就业增长强于预期，经济增长强于预期，而通胀率改善缓慢，根据美联储首选指标，9 月份通胀率为 3.4%，仍远高于目标。<正如政策制定者所说，央行有理由在批准任何进一步加息时“谨慎”。最值得注意的是基于市场的利率，无论美联储采取什么行动，投资者都推高了利率：自去年夏天以来，长期美国国债收益率飙升，30年期固定利率抵押贷款的平均利率也大幅上升。攀升至接近 8%，这是近四分之一个世纪以来未曾见过的水平。最终，美联储官员认为这些事态发展将减缓企业和家庭支出。

;

;但最近几周几乎没有明确说明这种情况何时会发生，就业、住房通胀、服务支出和其他方面期待已久的下降。关键数据点因经济不退出而推迟。

;

;即使是债券收益率的上升（一些美联储官员将其视为央行本身加息的替代品）也可能只是对经济增长的认可。经济实力强劲，并且暗示美联储可能需要采取更多行动来结束通胀斗争。

;

;花旗分析师在本周美联储会议之前写道：“我们认为，由于美国经济增长非常强劲，实际利率更高”会议。 “如果我们是对的，即使经济从第三季度 4.9% 的年增长率放缓，美联储也有可能落后于实际增长和通胀曲线。”

;

;美联储即将到期于美国东部时间下午 2 点（格林尼治标准时间 1800）发布最新政策声明。半小时后，美联储主席杰罗姆·鲍威尔将召开新闻发布会。

;

;投资者认为，美联储将把基准隔夜利率维持在 5.25%-5.50% 的区间内几乎是板上钉钉的事情。 7 月的会议，未来进一步加息的可能性也很大。

;

;由于本次会议没有发布最新的经济或利率预测，焦点将集中在新的政策声明还是鲍威尔的政策声明上。评论似乎倾向于或背离进一步加息。

;

;截至 9 月会议，美联储官员表示，他们仍然认为有必要再加息一次。如果说有什么不同的话，那就是此后的数据可能已经打开了大门。

;

;第三季度的国内生产总值增长最好地体现了美联储试图解析的风险，包括大流行时期的储蓄，加上低迷的经济状况。失业率和持续健康的工资增长，使消费者能够继续推动强劲的经济增长。这打消了人们的担忧，即重新支付学生贷款和消费者信心减弱等事态发展将导致人们撤退。

;

;相反，麦当劳和亚马逊等面向消费者的公司已经实现了高于共识的盈利，而房价却持续上涨尽管抵押贷款利率很高，但仍会上涨。

;

;自从大流行时代的计划向家庭银行账户注入了数万亿美元以来，经济学家一直试图接受这些额外储蓄何时会耗尽的问题。在美国政府公布;令人瞠目结舌的第三季度;经济增长数据后上周，一些分析师重新评估并表示，可能仍有 1 万亿美元的资金用于满足消费以及可能上涨的价格。

;

;“鉴于消费者的弹性，短期内的风险可能是牛津经济研究院首席美国经济学家南希·范登·霍顿（Nancy Vanden Houten）写道。 “很大程度上是所谓的‘报复性支出’......可能还有更多的运行空间，”她在提到大流行恢复期间出现的支出激增时说道。

;

;尽管根据世界大型企业联合会的数据，由于一系列担忧，消费者信心水平已降至衰退水平，但支出仍在持续增长。

;

;“消费者仍然关注整体价格上涨，以及食品杂货价格上涨世界大型企业联合会首席经济学家达纳·彼得森 (Dana Peterson) 周二在该商业集团报告其;十月份消费者预期指数;仍低于通常预示经济衰退即将到来的水平。 “消费者还表达了对政治局势和利率上升的担忧。在中东最近的动荡中，对战争/冲突的担忧也有所增加。”

;

;所有这些也都在美联储的考虑范围之内。 .

;

;鲍威尔近几个月表示，他认为美联储的政策总体上“符合预期”，借贷成本上升和金融条件收紧，最终导致经济放缓，但由于疫情持续存在，时间表可能会放慢储蓄激增和供需之间的严重失调（尤其是劳动力方面）等影响。换句话说，正在发生的事情可能只是缓慢而痛苦地调整回 2% 的通胀目标，这是如果替代方案是失业率大幅上升和不必要的衰退，美联储不会想仓促行事。

;

;但鲍威尔也表示，增长需要放缓 - 如果不放缓，这意味着美联储的政策利率需要走得更高。

;

;“经济强劲是一件好事。经济能够在我们实施的紧缩政策下保持稳定，这是一件好事。劳动力市场强劲是一件好事，”鲍威尔在 9 月 19 日至 20 日政策会议结束后的新闻发布会上表示。但“如果经济强于预期，那就意味着我们必须采取行动货币政策方面更要回到2%。因为我们会回到 2%。”

;;加拿大总理贾斯汀·特鲁多和财政部长克里斯蒂亚·弗里兰在加拿大安大略省渥太华的国会山上拿着 2023-24 年预算散步， 2023 年 3 月 28 日。路透社/Patrick Doyle/档案照片;
;

;以加拿大为例;经济学家表示，总理贾斯汀·特鲁多应该应对可能的经济衰退;和二十多年来最高的债务成本;遏制他的消费习惯;，以确保未来的政策选择不会强加给他。

;

;特鲁多的自由党政府以大胆支出而闻名。 2015年，由于民意调查落后，他承诺通过赤字来加强公共基础设施并赢得选举。在疫情造成的经济动荡中，他的政府出现了加拿大有史以来最高的赤字。

;

;然而，偿债成本已接近收入的 10%，一些经济学家表示，为了不造成负担，需要设定一个上限。子孙后代或面临削减政府计划的风险。他们表示，在最近几周全球债券收益率飙升之后，这些债务支付可能会进一步增加。

;

;如果现在无法抑制支出，可能会面临“市场决定你必须如何制定财政政策”的风险。 BMO 资本市场首席经济学家道格·波特 (Doug Porter)。

;

;“我确实认为他们必须稍微调整一下风帆，”他补充道。

;

;但看起来可能会有更多支出在途中。财政部长克里斯蒂亚·弗里兰预计将在秋季经济声明 (FES) 中公布措施，该声明最早可能于下周发布，其中包括帮助加拿大人解决住房和负担能力问题的工具。

;

;财政部，援引国际货币基金组织的话说，该国的赤字和净债务与国内生产总值的比率是七国集团中最低的。

;

;“加拿大的经济计划是健全的、可持续的且财政上负责任的，”凯瑟琳·库普林斯卡​​斯说，该部发言人。

;

;特鲁多现在面临着自掌权以来的最低民调支持率，但与 2015 年不同的是，赤字支出无法缓解;他的受欢迎程度下降;，却没有使加拿大央行 (BoC) 复杂化;努力平息通货膨胀;。

;

;根据当前的支出计划，联邦和省政府已经加拿大央行行长蒂夫·麦克莱姆 (Tiff Macklem) 上周对记者表示，明年的通胀将会加剧。

;

;“如果货币政策和财政政策朝着同一方向发展，那么降低通胀将会更容易，”麦克莱姆表示。

;

;特鲁多政府表示，通过将债务与国内生产总值的比率在中期下降来保持其财政前景。如果他们想实现这一目标，额外支出的空间很小，特别是因为经济似乎;已经处于浅度衰退;。

;

;加拿大的广义政府净债务（包括省级和市级借款，但因养老金资产而减少）是迄今为止最低的其债务总额在七国集团国家中名列前茅，但据国际货币基金组织数据显示，到 2023 年，其总债务预计将占 GDP 的 106.4%，高于德国和英国。

;

;今年，政府继续在以下方面支出： Desjardins 经济学家 Randall Bartlett 表示：“他们正在迅速耗尽现有的任何财政空间。”他估计政府每年可以支出约 130 亿加元（94 亿美元）来控制债务与 GDP 的比率上升，但那是在夏季之前。

;

;政府尚未计算这笔额外费用RBC Dominion 加拿大利率策略主管 Simon Deeley 表示，近几个月国债发行量高是政府财政状况弱于预期的另一个可能迹象。证券公司

;

;如果反对派新民主党继续支持他的少数派政府，特鲁多可能会再执政两年，直到他的任期结束。

;

;但这种支持伴随着昂贵的要求，议会预算官员估计，其中包括关于支付处方药的国家计划的立法，仅第一年就将花费 112 亿加元。

;

;“如果他们继续进行诸如药物保险之类的事情，或者更多加拿大商业委员会政策高级副总裁、前财政部官员罗伯特·阿瑟林 (Robert Asselin) 表示：“如果在住房问题上采取积极态度，信用评级机构将开始提出很多问题。”

;

;惠誉评级剥夺了加拿大的信用评级2020 年 6 月，其信用评级为 3A，理由是大流行病支出。穆迪投资者服务公司、标准普尔全球评级和 DBRS 晨星继续给予加拿大最高评级。

;

;“我们正在监控该国的政治动态，”标准普尔全球评级加拿大首席分析师朱莉娅·史密斯 (Julia Smith) 表示，并补充说，随着偿债成本上升和增长放缓，“必须就其他政策举措做出一些可能的决定”。

;

;（1 美元 = 1.3848 加元）

; Wed, 01 Nov 2023 18:55:03 +0800 Republican US senator presses Fed officials on bond-buying policieshttps://reuters.com/article/usa-fed-powell-letter/republican-us-senator-presses-fed-officials-on-bond-buying-policies-idUSKBN31W2L6
;;2023-11-01T10:12:30Z;
;

;（路透社）- 美国参议员里克·斯科特（Rick Scott）是美联储债券购买计划的激烈批评者，他已发送了一份致央行主席杰罗姆·鲍威尔的新信抱怨佛罗里达州共和党人认为从其资产负债表中剥离资产的进展缓慢。

;;
;;文件照片：美国参议员里克·斯科特（Rick Scott）（佛罗里达州共和党）出席共和党每周例会2023 年 9 月 19 日在美国华盛顿美国国会大厦举行的政策午餐会。路透社/Evelyn Hockstein/档案照片;
;

;斯科特周一发送给鲍威尔的信，此前他最近发送了一系列信件向最新的美联储董事会成员——美联储副主席菲利普·杰斐逊（Philip Jefferson）以及州长丽莎·库克（Lisa Cook）和阿德里亚娜·库格勒（Adriana Kugler）——寻求他们在美联储正在进行的资产负债表削减计划中的立场。美联储削减约一万亿美元债券的速度比央行行长们预期的要慢。

;

;“很明显，你们目前削减资产负债表的计划是不够的，而且永远无法解决问题你庞大的资产负债表，”斯科特写道。 “对我来说，为什么你不能以增加资产负债表的速度来减少资产负债表，这对我来说毫无意义。”

;

;斯科特还询问美联储是否会采取更“积极”的资产负债表缩减立场.

;

;美联储允许每月近 1000 亿美元的国库券和抵押贷款债券到期且无需更换。尽管一些央行行长曾考虑过在某个时候出售抵押贷款债券，但它并没有积极出售任何证券。

;

;美联储长期以来一直面临资产购买可能扭曲金融市场的批评，其规模增加了一倍多2020 年春季至 2022 年夏季期间，其资产负债表的规模达到了接近 9 万亿美元的峰值。

;

;斯科特在接受采访时表示，他尚未收到对其信件的任何回复。美联储发言人表示，央行计划做出回应。

;

;斯科特在一月份向鲍威尔询问了类似信息。斯科特办公室的一位发言人表示，斯科特尚未收到书面答复，但在过去几年与央行行长的面对面会议上讨论了资产负债表问题。

;美国最高法院将于周三考虑加州律师是否可以拥有包含“<针对反对意见的 href="/legal/trump-too-small-t-shirt-slogan-turns-into-us-supreme-court-battle-2023-10-27/">;特朗普太小;”美国专利商标局就商标与宪法言论自由权之间的相互作用展开法律斗争。

;

;法官们将听取该机构对下级法院推翻其驳回决定的上诉的论据律师史蒂夫·埃尔斯特 (Steve Elster) 申请的商标“Trump Too Small”（对前总统唐纳德·特朗普 (Donald Trump) 的不敬批评）在 T 恤上使用。

;

;埃尔斯特 (Elster) 于 2018 年申请了该商标，援引了特朗普和特朗普之间的交流美国参议员马可·卢比奥 (Marco Rubio) 在 2016 年共和党总统提名候选人辩论中。特朗普早些时候曾侮辱卢比奥为“小马可”。卢比奥反驳说特朗普的手小得不成比例。

;

;“看看那些手。它们是小手吗？”特朗普在辩论中问道。 “如果它们很小，其他东西也一定很小。我向你保证，没有问题。我保证。”

;

;埃尔斯特说，“特朗普太小”表达了他对“唐纳德的小”的看法特朗普的总体执政方式。”提出申请时特朗普是总统。

;

;特朗普目前是 2024 年美国大选中挑战民主党总统乔·拜登的共和党提名领跑者，他本人并未参与此案，也没有对此发表评论.

;

;商标局根据 1946 年的联邦法律拒绝了埃尔斯特的申请，该法律禁止在未经许可的情况下在商标中使用某人的姓名。但联邦上诉法院;站在埃尔斯特一边; ，发现政府保护公众人物隐私和形象权的利益并没有取代埃尔斯特批评他们的权利，这一权利受到美国宪法第一修正案的保护。

;

;埃尔斯特的申请仍被该机构搁置，等待审理最高法院预计将于 6 月底做出裁决。

;

;近年来，最高法院以言论自由问题为由废除了两项商标法。 2017 年，该法院做出有利于亚裔美国摇滚乐队 The Slants 的裁决，反对禁止使用“贬低”的商标，并支持艺术家 Erik Brunetti 在其“FUCT”争议中反对禁止“不道德”或“诽谤性”商标。 ” 2019 年的品牌。

;

;拜登政府告诉最高法院，现在有争议的法律有所不同，因为它不会根据申请人的观点限制言论，而只是为了防止一个人的名字“被利用他人的商业利益。”

;

;它还表示，法律并不阻止埃尔斯特使用该短语，并将其描述为“政府利益的条件，而不是对言论的限制”。政府提出了自己的言论自由问题，认为像埃尔斯特这样的商标通过赋予个人对政治短语的合法所有权来限制他人的言论。

;

;埃尔斯特告诉法官，公众人物可以滥用法律来压制他人的言论。批评，指出“Joe 2020”和“Hillary For America”的商标被授予，但“No Joe in 2024”和“Hillary for Prison 2016”被拒绝。

;< 31 岁的班克曼-弗里德 (Bankman-Fried) 可能会在 FTX 在一场迅速的企业崩溃中申请破产后得知自己的命运，这场公司崩溃震惊了金融市场，并抹去了他估计的 260 亿美元的财富。检察官指控他在美国历史上最大的金融欺诈案之一中盗窃了 80 亿美元。

;

;在班克曼-弗里德接受检方第二天严格的盘问后，他的律师于周二搁置了案件 -他选择为自己的辩护作证所冒的风险。班克曼-弗里德对两项欺诈罪和五项共谋罪不认罪，并在三天内对 ;让; 12名陪审员相信他是无罪的。

;

;陪审团在曼哈顿联邦法院总共听取了15天的证词。班克曼-弗里德的三名前密友在认罪后为检方作证，称班克曼-弗里德指示他们去;commit financial crimes;, including helping his crypto-focused Alameda Research hedge fund siphon FTX customer deposits and lying to lenders and investors about the finances of the two companies.

;< p>;Prosecutors have said Bankman-Fried used the money he looted from customers to pay off Alameda lenders, make speculative investments and donate to US political candidates. They also have said he lured customers to FTX with false promises that the exchange prioritized keeping their funds safe and did not give Alameda favored treatment, and gave false assurances about FTX's health to slow a wave of withdrawals.

;

;Under questioning from his lawyer Mark Cohen, Bankman-Fried portrayed himself as a busy CEO who left operational nuts and bolts to subordinates. He also maintained that while he made mistakes that harmed customers and employees, he never defrauded anyone or stole money.

;

;Danielle Sassoon, one of the prosecutors, tried to counter that narrative by grilling Bankman-Fried about statements he made before his December 2022 arrest about the safety of customer funds and Alameda's independence from FTX. ;During his second day of testimony on Monday - when the prosecution began its cross-examination - Bankman-Fried said "I don't recall" at least 28 times. US District Judge Lewis Kaplan frequently chided him for evading direct answers.

;Closing arguments probably will take several hours, and jurors are not expected to get the case before Thursday.

;Bankman-Fried could face decades in prison if convicted on all counts. He has been jailed since August after Kaplan revoked his bail, having concluded that he likely tampered with witnesses.

;Apple investors will have one big question when the world's most valuable company reports earnings on Thursday - will Huawei's resurgence in China dampen its holiday-quarter expectations?

;;Crowds were seen gathered outside Gaza's Rafah border crossing on Wednesday (November 1) morning, as an agreement was brokered that would allow the movement of foreign passport holders and some critically injured people into Egypt, a source briefed on deal told Reuters.;
;

;A first group of injured evacuees from Gaza crossed into Egypt on Wednesday under a Qatari-mediated deal, Egyptian media and a 7source at the border said, as Israeli forces pressed their battle against Hamas militants in the Palestinian enclave.

;

;The evacuees were driven in ambulances through the Rafah border crossing. Under the deal reached between Egypt, Israel and Hamas, a number of foreigners and critically wounded people will be allowed to leave the besieged territory.

;

;The evacuation followed another day of bloodshed in Gaza in which an Israeli air strike on Tuesday killed about 50 people in a refugee camp, according to Palestinian health officials.

;

;Israel said the attack killed a senior Hamas commander and many other combatants.

;

;Israel sent its forces into Hamas-controlled Gaza following weeks of air and artillery bombardments in retaliation for a deadly attack by the Islamist group on southern Israel on Oct 7.

;

;Israel has vowed to wipe out Hamas. But the civilian death toll in Gaza and the desperate humanitarian conditions have caused great concern across the world as food, fuel, drinking water and medicine run short and hospitals struggle to treat casualties.

;

;An Egyptian security source had said earlier that up to 500 foreign passport holders will pass the Rafah border crossing on Wednesday. About 200 people were waiting at the Palestinian side of the border on Wednesday morning, the source said.

;

;A second source said not all were expected to make it out on Wednesday. There was no timeline for how long the crossing will remain open for evacuation, they added.

;

;A Western official said a list of people with foreign passports who can leave Gaza had been agreed between Israel and Egypt and relevant embassies have been informed. An Israeli official who requested anonymity confirmed that Israel was coordinating the exits with Egypt.

;

;Egypt has prepared a field hospital in Sheikh Zuwayed in the Sinai, medical sources said. Ambulances could be seen waiting at the Rafah crossing.

;

;The first source said this deal, however, was not linked to other issues, such as the release of about 240 hostages held by Hamas or a "humanitarian pause" in the fighting which many countries have called for but which Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has rejected.

;

;The Hamas attack on southern Israel on Oct. 7 killed about 300 soldiers and some 1,100 civilians, Israeli figures say.

;

;At least 8,525 Palestinians, including 3,542 children, were killed in retaliatory Israeli strikes on Gaza since Oct.7, the Gaza health ministry says.

;

;The Israeli military said Tuesday's strikes on Jabalia, Gaza's largest refugee camp, had killed Ibrahim Biari, a Hamas commander it said was pivotal in organising the Oct. 7 assault, as well as dozens of Hamas militants.

;

;Palestinian health officials said at least 50 Palestinians were killed and 150 wounded, while a Hamas statement said there were 400 dead and injured in Jabalia, which houses families of refugees from wars with Israel dating back to 1948.

;

;Hamas' armed wing al-Qassam Brigades said seven civilian hostages were killed in the Jabalia attack, including three foreign passport holders. There was no comment from Israel on the claim.

;

;Eleven Israeli soldiers were also killed in fighting on Tuesday, the Israeli military said, its biggest one-day loss since the initial assault.

;

;Netanyahu mourned mounting military losses but said the war would be long but victorious.

;

;"We are in a tough war. It will be a long war," he said in a statement. "I promise to all citizens of Israel: We will get the job done. We will press ahead until victory."

;

;After a lull of several hours in rocket fire, the Israeli military sounded sirens in southern communities as well as the port cities of Ashkelon and Ashdod.

;

;The din of Israeli war planes, tanks and naval boats pounding Gaza city and the north continued all through the night. Israeli ground forces clashed with fighters from Hamas and other groups in the north, southern and eastern areas of Gaza - part of a series of incursions apparently aimed at incremental gains rather than a full-scale invasion.

;

;Communications and internet services were completely cut off in Gaza again on Wednesday, telecommunications provider Paltel said.

;

;"They don't want the world to see their crimes against civilians," said Gaza resident Ahmed Muhey.

;

;Dozens of Palestinians gathered outside the Nasser Hospital morgue waiting to get the bodies of their relatives for burial.

;

;Inside, bodies lay on the ground being prepared to be shrouded in white after they were cleaned of dust and blood.

;

;Health officials said they had received 15 bodies of Palestinians killed in Israeli strikes overnight in Khan Younis, including four children.

;

;"Everyday there are dead and every day there are children or women among them or both," said one doctor.

;

;Two of Gaza's main hospitals - Al Shifa Medical and the Indonesian Hospital - faced a power outage as their generators rapidly run out of fuel.

;

;The current violence - the worst in many years of sporadic warfare - erupted at a time when Palestinian hopes for an independent state and an end to Israel's occupation are as far away as ever. Peace talks are now just a distant memory and Netanyahu's right-wing government has expanded Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank.

;

;Israel sees Hamas, which has vowed to destroy the Jewish state, as an existential threat.

;

;US Secretary of State Antony Blinken, who will visit Israel on Friday, said the United States and other countries were looking at "a variety of possible permutations" for the ;future; of Gaza if Hamas militants are removed from control.

;

;Iran supports Hamas, as well as several other militant groups in the region, and the conflict in Gaza has triggered fears of a wider escalation.

;

;On Wednesday, the Israeli military said it had deployed missile boats in the Red Sea, following long-range drone and missile attacks claimed by the Houthis in Yemen.

; Wed, 01 Nov 2023 18:55:03 +0800 Futures slip as investors await Fed rate verdicthttps://reuters.com/article/usa-stocks/futures-slip-as-investors-await-fed-rate-verdict-idUSKBN31W2K1
;;2023-11-01T09:51:38Z;
;;
;;Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, US, October 27, 2023. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid;
;

;US stock index futures drifted lower on Wednesday as longer-dated Treasury yields rose ahead of the Federal Reserve's monetary policy decision at the end of its two-day meeting.

;

;The Fed is widely expected to keep interest rates unchanged but investors will focus on Fed Chair Jerome Powell's conference at 1430 ET (1830 GMT) after the statement to gauge how long the central bank could keep rates elevated.

;

;Traders' bets of a 25 basis point rate hike in December currently stand at 27.4%, as per CME Group's FedWatch tool.

;

;"We know that Jerome Powell won't call the end of the policy tightening after seeing a blowout growth data," said Ipek Ozkardeskaya, senior analyst at Swissquote Bank, referring to a robust third-quarter US gross domestic product (GDP) report.

;

;Weighing on sentiment, the yield on the 10-year note rose to 4.905% while that on the two-year note , which best reflects short-term rate expectations, was largely steady at 5.07%.

;

;The Fed's messaging on interest rates will likely set the tone for US equities following a sharp fall in October due to a surge in Treasury yields, the Middle East conflict and mixed earnings reports.

;

;Among major movers, ;Advanced Micro Devices; ;(AMD.O); slipped 2.4% in premarket trading after the chipmaker forecast fourth-quarter revenue and gross margins below Wall Street estimates.

;

;CVS Health ;(CVS.N);, Humana ;(HUM.N); and Estee Lauder ;(EL.N); are among major companies reporting earnings on Wednesday.

;

;Overall, analysts expect earnings growth of 4.9% for S&P 500 companies in the third quarter, per LSEG data, a sharp improvement over the 1.6% growth forecast at the beginning of October.

;

;Investors will also parse through a slew of data on the labor market, including the ADP National Employment report and a reading on job openings later on Wednesday, ahead of the monthly payrolls report for October on Friday.

;

;The Institute for Supply Management's (ISM) survey on manufacturing activity last month will also provide more clues on the strength of the economy.

;

;The release of quarterly refunding details from the Treasury Department will also be in focus on Wednesday, given a sharp rise in longer-dated bond yields in recent weeks that has fueled concerns about the US fiscal deficit.

;

;Analysts have cautioned that any surprises to the upside may push the 10-year yield higher, likely piling more pressure on stocks.

;

;At 5:17 am ET, Dow e-minis were down 106 points, or 0.32%, S&P 500 e-minis were down 13.5 points, or 0.32%, and Nasdaq 100 e-minis were down 49.25 points, or 0.34%.

;

;Shares of payroll processor ;Paycom Software; ;(PAYC.N); plunged 35.6% premarket on a downbeat fourth-quarter revenue outlook, while First Solar ;(FSLR.O); gained 4.4% as the solar panel maker raised the lower end of its full-year profit forecast.

; Wed, 01 Nov 2023 17:55:03 +0800 Biden kicks off rural America tour in Minnesotahttps://reuters.com/article/usa-biden-rural/biden-kicks-off-rural-america-tour-in-minnesota-idUSKBN31W2HB
;;2023-11-01T09:02:36Z;
;

;US President Joe Biden will tout $5 billion in new investments benefiting rural Americans during a visit on Wednesday to a family farm in Minnesota, the first stop in what the White House is billing as a two-week "barnstorming" tour.

;

;Thirteen top administration officials will visit rural places in 15 states, including election battlegrounds like Michigan, Pennsylvania and Arizona, to highlight investments in rural communities, where one in five Americans live.

;

;The Minnesota event will showcase top Democratic officials from the state in a show of support for Biden just days after Minnesota lawmaker ;Dean Phillips; launched a primary challenge to a sitting president, sources familiar with the plans said.

;

;A campaign official told Reuters that Biden would also participate in a fundraiser in Minneapolis after the farm visit.

;

;The official noted that Democrats improved their margins in rural areas in 2022 compared to 2020, winning over former supporters of former President Donald Trump.

;

;"We are treating these 2022 newly Democratic voters as key persuasion targets for 2024 and are not taking any vote (rural/suburban/urban) for granted," the official added.

;

;White House spokesperson Karine Jean-Pierre did not link the president's visit to Phillips' long-shot challenge, but said the administration was "thankful" to Phillips for voting nearly 100% with Biden over the past two years.

;

;"Minnesota is an important state that the president wanted to go and visit," she said, adding that Biden planned to speak directly with rural Americans - who account for about 20% of the US population - about how his legislation is creating jobs in their communities and other urgently needed investments.

;

;Biden beat former president Donald Trump in Minnesota by 52.4% to 45.3%, winning the state's 10 electoral college votes out of a total of 538 total.

;

;The Democratic president arrives in Minnesota amid ;mounting criticism by Muslim and Arab Americans; of his support for Israel's bombardment of the Gaza Strip.

;

;Jaylani Hussein, executive director of the Council of American Islamic Relations (CAIR) for Minnesota, said Arab and Muslim American leaders and their allies would protest Biden's Israel policy, at the Minneapolis-St Paul International Airport at 1 pm, at the farm he is visiting, and in downtown Minneapolis at 5 pm

;

;White House officials had no immediate comment on the planned protests.

;

;"President Biden believes that investing in America means investing in all of America and leaving no one behind," Neera Tanden, who heads the White House Domestic Policy Council, told reporters. "That means young people in rural communities should not have to leave home to find opportunity."

;

;Reuters reported in September that the White House and Biden's campaign planned an ;aggressive outreach to rural voters,; who account for 30% of the electorate in swing states North Carolina, Georgia and Wisconsin, and around 22% in Pennsylvania.

;

;Biden's campaign is actively targeting Black farmers with a new television ad that will run in Raleigh, North Carolina and on national cable news, the third campaign ad targeting Black Americans.

;

;It is part of a 16-week, $25 million advertising campaign targeting key voters in battleground states, that are hotly contested because their voting preferences can swing either to Republicans or Democrats.

;

;Getting credit for economic gains is crucial to Biden's 2024 reelection, but many rural voters feel frustrated and disengaged after decades of industrial decline and job losses in the face of globalization and declining agriculture.

;

;During his visit to Dutch Creek Farms in Northfield, Biden plans to announce over $5 billion in new investments for rural America drawn from the Inflation Reduction Act, a $1 trillion bipartisan infrastructure law and reprogramming of existing funds, White House officials said.

;

;The money includes $1.7 billion to support climate-smart agriculture practices, $1.1 billion in investments in clean water and other infrastructure, and $2 billion for economic development projects in nine states and Puerto Rico, along with additional investments in expanding broadband access.
